Document Title: Spatio-Temporal Urban Growth Pattern in the Arctic: A Case Study in Surgut, Russia
Authors: C. Ourng; Y. Vaguet; A. Derkacheva
Author Affiliations: UMR 6266 I.D.E.E.S., University of Rouen, Mont-Saint-Aignan, France; UMR 6266 I.D.E.E.S., University of Rouen, Mont-Saint-Aignan, France; Faculty of Geography, Moscow State University, Moscow, Russia
Abstract: A spatial-temporal analysis has become an essential approach for tracking the trend of changes in land use and land cover pattern especially in the context of urbanization. This paper presents the urban land use change over time of an Arctic pioneer town, Surgut (Russia). This town unfolds during the soviet era, embedded with oil production, and grew up to become the country oil capital. Surgut is nowadays one of the healthier Russian Arctic towns and has always been attractive even during the severe decrease in population of the Russian Arctic zone over the decade of the USSR collapse. Various multi-temporal satellite imageries (1973-2018) were used to generate the map and analyze the urban expansion, land transformation, and growth directions in order to understand the nature of built-up growth in a soviet Arctic city and its post-soviet evolution.
INSPEC Controlled Terms: geographic information systems;geophysical image processing;land cover;land use;remote sensing;town and country planning
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: spatio-temporal urban growth pattern;Surgut;spatial-temporal analysis;land cover pattern;urban land use change;Arctic pioneer town;soviet era;oil production;healthier Russian Arctic towns;Russian Arctic zone;multitemporal satellite imageries;urban expansion;land transformation;soviet Arctic city

Document Title: Structural Health Monitoring on Urban Areas by Using Multi Temporal Insar and Deep Learning
Authors: G. Martin; S. Selvakumaran; A. Marinoni; Z. Sadeghi; C. Middleton
Author Affiliations: Dept. of Engineering, Centre for Digital Built Britain, University of Cambridge; Dept. of Engineering, University of Cambridge; Dept. of Physics and Technology, UiT the Arctic University of Norway; COMET, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds; Dept. of Engineering, University of Cambridge
Publication Title: 2021 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium IGARSS
Abstract: The recent advancements in machine learning techniques have opened the door for automatic large scale monitoring of the surface of the earth. For instance, they could be used in order to evaluate and assess civil infrastructures at scale, which is costly due to the fact that typically the existing methods rely on in-situ evaluation. Over the last decade Deep Learning technologies have risen as the state of the art methods for many different machine learning problems due to the fact that they can learn complex features and model complex non-linear behaviours. In this paper we will explore the possibility of using Deep Learning technologies over remote sensing data with the aim of structure health monitoring at scale. We will compare the performance of new Deep Learning technologies with regards to other traditional machine learning methods. For this purpose, we will use InSAR (Interferometry Synthetic Aperture Radar) data which allow us to measure cumulative surface displacement in the line of sight of the sensor with millimetric accuracy. We will analyse multi temporal InSAR data in order to model ground subsidence. In this paper we will discuss how deep learning technologies can learn to detect terrain subsidence over multi-temporal InSAR data automatically, providing much better results than traditional methods.
Funding Information: Centre for Integrated Remote Sensing and Forecasting for Arctic Operations (CIRFA) and the Research Council of Norway(grant numbers:237906);
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Machine learning algorithms;Urban areas;Time series analysis;Clustering algorithms;Task analysis;Sustainable development
INSPEC Controlled Terms: condition monitoring;learning (artificial intelligence);radar imaging;radar interferometry;remote sensing;remote sensing by radar;synthetic aperture radar
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: urban areas;machine learning techniques;in-situ evaluation;different machine learning problems;deep learning technologies;remote sensing data;structure health monitoring;traditional machine learning methods;multitemporal InSAR data;structural health monitoring

Document Title: Feasibility analysis of airfield selection based on multi-temporal and multi-mission remote sensing data
Authors: J. Liu; X. Cui; Y. Tian; B. Sun; A. Markov; D. Lv; G. Hai; G. Qiao; T. Feng; R. Li
Author Affiliations: Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Polar Research Institute of China, Shanghai, China; Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Polar Research Institute of China, Shanghai, China; College of Construction Engineering, Polar Research Center Jilin University, Changchun, China; Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China; Center for Spatial Information Science and Sustainable Development Application, Tongji University, Shanghai, China
Publication Title: 2019 10th International Workshop on the Analysis of Multitemporal Remote Sensing Images (MultiTemp)
Abstract: As the polar region has attracted growing attention around the world, field expeditions to Antarctica have become increasingly frequent. To provide take-off and landing capabilities for the wheeled aircraft of Chinese Antarctic Research Expeditions (CHINAREs), we use multi-mission and multitemporal remote sensing data to analyse the feasibility of blue ice airfield selection near Zhongshan Station, East Antarctica, and recommended two top-ranked runway candidates. This airfield selection method may be applied to other areas of Antarctica as well as Greenland and Arctic regions.
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: Chinese Antarctic Research Expeditions;multitemporal remote sensing data;blue ice airfield selection;East Antarctica;airfield selection method;feasibility analysis;multimission remote sensing data;polar region;field expeditions;landing capabilities;wheeled aircraft

Document Title: Sentinel 1 Radar Data Use to Recognize Thawed/Frozen Soil State in Some Russian Arctic Regions in 2017–2018
Author Affiliations: Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics, Russian Academy of Sciences, Fryazino, Russian Federation
Publication Title: 2019 Russian Open Conference on Radio Wave Propagation (RWP)
Abstract: This paper deals with the identification of thawed/frozen soils in the topsoil layer for three stations in Russia: Salekhard, Tiksi and Norilsk by using Sentinel 1B C-band radar data for the period of 2017-2018. The determining of the frozen/thawed soil state is carried out in three ways: 1) by multi-temporal radar data on the basis of a significant in 3-5 dB the backscatter coefficient difference in the transition to freezing/thawing soil state, 2) by finding the threshold value of the backscatter coefficient at which the temperature in the topsoil layer falls below 00C, 3) by texture features.
Author Keywords: C-band radar data;backscattering coefficient;air temperature;soil freezing/thawing state;Spearman correlation coefficient
INSPEC Controlled Terms: hydrological techniques;remote sensing by radar;soil;spaceborne radar
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: topsoil layer;Sentinel 1B C-band radar data;multitemporal radar data;Sentinel 1 radar data use;backscatter coefficient;Russian Arctic regions;Salekhard;Tiksi;Norilsk;noise figure 3.0 dB to 5.0 dB

Document Title: Retrieval of Mass Balance of Austre Grønfjordbreen in the Western Svalbard
Authors: Rajat; B. R. Nela; G. Singh; V. Singh Rathore; A. F. Glazovsky
Author Affiliations: Department of Remote Sensing, Birla Institute of Technology Mesra, Ranchi, India; Centre of Studies in Resources Engineering, IIT Bombay, Mumbai, India; Centre of Studies in Resources Engineering, IIT Bombay, Mumbai, India; Department of Remote Sensing, Birla Institute of Technology Mesra, Ranchi, India; Russian Academy of Sciences, Institute of Geography, Moscow, Russia
Publication Title: 2021 IEEE International India Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (InGARSS)
Abstract: In this study, the geodetic method was used to infer glacier mass balance, and its spatial variation over glaciers, in the part of Svalbard (Arctic).The study proposed an adaptive mass balance inversion algorithm developed using different densities for ice and firn. Firn identification was achieved through the multi-temporal SAR approach. The performance of the mass balance retrieval algorithm was validated with the ground-based measured mass balance over the Austre Grønfjordbreen, Svalbard. Using elevation rate of change and density (900 ±10 kg/m3) for ice and firn (600 ±200 kg/m3) areas, mass balance is estimated. The mean of geodetic mass balance is found to be -1.47 ± 0.01 m w. e. a-1 with constant density and -1.40 ± 0.06 m w. e. a-1 with the consideration of adaptive density for ice and firn area and then compared with field data (-1.38 m w. e. a-1). The mean mass balance of the proposed method is near to the field based calculated mass balance.
IEEE Terms: Geoscience and remote sensing;Estimation;Ice;Synthetic aperture radar;Monitoring
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: Austre Grønfjordbreen;glacier mass balance;Svalbard;adaptive mass balance inversion algorithm;ice;mass balance retrieval algorithm;geodetic mass balance;firn area;mean mass balance;size -1.48 m to -1.46 m;size -1.46 m to -1.3399999999999999 m;size -1.38 m
